title: PrintrBot Simple Metal Power Switch Panel

description.text: I don't like pulling the power lead out of my power adaptor to switch off the printer, and also wanted an emergency stop switch on the front of the machine, so created this model in 123D Design to accommodate said switch.. The panel is designed to fit in with the Printrbot aesthetics, and the switch cut-out is sized to fit a basic illuminated rocker switch (in my case Maplin part number N84JZ http://www.maplin.co.uk/p/rectangular-12v-rocker-switch-illuminated-red-n84jz). I'll put a blog post up about the wiring in case anybody wants to do the same. Please go to http://www.soldersuckerblog.com/home/random-ramblings. Once I create the blog entry, I'll update this link direct to the post. If you're wondering about the slot on the top...it's there to house the small Delrin spacer supplied with the Printrbot kit - I use it to smooth down tape on the build platform and was always losing it! This is my first design on Thingiverse, I've downloaded so many great models I wanted to give back - I hope it's useful for others!

I wanted to keep the design simple (I'm a sucker for over-engineering...) so the box is mounted by using a small amount of hot glue on the rear wings of the box. The bottom is left open to allow cables to pass underneath and into the machine.
Print face down with a 15% infill and use support material for the rear wings. I found that 'pillar' style support worked best for me.

comments.text: Not related to this print but just thought I'd point out - those feet are supposed to be printed as perimeter only, no infill or top/bottom layers. By removing the infill, they will have a bit of springiness to act as vibration isolators.

Clock needles replacement.
If you collect the Halloween village pieces, you've probably seen something similar on sale for many tens of dollars. Build your own instead!

You'll need some 1/8" craft wood sticks cut to the following dimensions:
12 x 93mm
4 x 84mm
4 x 68mm
You'll also need to print out 8 joiners, 4 pole segments and 1 of everything else. All parts except the ladder snap together, but a little glue won't hurt. Glue the ladder onto the back supports. Use a raft for pretty much all parts except the base, and the pumpkin needs supports as well. I left the raft on the bottom pole segment. Drop an LED light in under the pumpkin for maximum spooky effect.

author: walshy002000

description.text: Finned balloon shaped lamp, with triple 1 W LEDs

This desk lamp is printed in three parts
The Lampshade, the lamp lower and the cell triple base
It requires the following components. I have included some sample items from Amazon
Three high high watt LEDs
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008DBV26O/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Three heat sink LED stars
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BSR2D1S/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Thermal adhesive to attach the LEDs to the heat sinks
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0009IQ1BU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
A SPST toggle switch
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008ICKO30/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
A 12v power supply
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005JRGOCM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
A power socket to match the power supply
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EQ1UWX4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Three M3 screws
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00032Q1J4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
A 2W 10 Ohm ballast resistor
You can calculate the value of the resistor using the website below
http://www.resistorguide.com/resistor-for-led/
Assembling the lamp
Print the three STL files, I print the cell triple base and the lamp lower together and the lampshade separately with a brim.
If you are assembling the LEDs onto the heat sink stars, then you can either use surface mount reflow paste in a skillet (just search you tube) or I used thermal adhesive to glue the center pad of the LED to the star, then soldered the contacts in place. Alternatively you can buy the stars preassembled.
Next wire the three LEDs in series in the same direction. With the two end wires left longer. Place the three stars into the triple cell print.
Wire the positive of the LED’s to one terminal of the toggle switch, wired the negative to the ballast resistor. Connect the other end of the ballast resistor to the negative terminal of the power socket.
Connect the positive on the power socket to the other pole on the switch.
Tap the three holes in the lampshade pat with an M3x6 tap.
Screw the triple cell base to the lampshade with three M3 screws.
Assemble the base inserting the switch and the socket into the two holes (they are different sized.
Use a few dabs of superglue to glue the triple cell base to the lamp lower and ensuring that the three holes in the base line up with the M3 screws.

comments.text: I have followed your instructions and hoping to upload my version with led's but for one problem, the resistor gets incredibly hot within seconds, burning to touch, I am using exactly the parts you listed apart from my psu is 12v 500mA.  Any suggestions? The balloon lamp prints beautifully.
comments.author: geekmaster

comments.text:
Did you use a 2 watt resistor.. mine get hot (but not as hot as the heat syncs for the LEDs.. I checked it out with a temperature gun and it stabilized out at a constant temperature.
if you increase the size of the resistor, you will get less current and hence less power (and dimmer LEDs).. maybe your LEDs don't quite have the same forward voltage? if they are dropping less than 3.2v each then there will be more voltage (and power) going through the resistor.
check out this guys instructable on driving LEDs http://www.instructables.com/id/Circuits-for-using-High-Power-LED-s/
you could use one of those circuits instead of just a resistor.
comments.author: geekmaster

comments.text: Yes the ones I've printed so far are in PLA (at 220 degrees ) the 48c was before I assembled the lamp I had it running  for about an hour and that temp was the max temp the  LED heat sink stars got to. I wanted to make sure the LEDs wouldn't get to a dangerous temperature and cause a fire. They seem to be fine. I've them running  all day with no problems. ( I do turn them off when I  leave the house though just to be sure)

comments.text: Love the design!  I'd love to print one in PLA - was the 48c temp the max for the LED's?

Markerbot is a low-cost robot designed to get young kids programming. The robot features an IR reader which allows kids to program the robot to do whatever they want by simply coloring in the appropriate arrows on a paper strip. Four IR sensors are positioned along the circumference of the reader and pick up their respective column of tick marks on the strip of paper. The fourth column on the strip is pre-printed with a set of tick marks to indicate when the other sensors should check to see if tick marks are in their own column. The code running on the Arduino splits the strip into 3x3 chunks and extracts the various movement commands to be executed once the "Go!" button is pushed. This was made for a robotics class. Check out a video of it in action as well as some of the other students' designs...
https://sites.google.com/site/me842010/home/markerbot

Assembly:
  • Print the circular reader housing. This may or may not be possible on a Makerbot. I suspect with the right settings and orientation it can be done.
  • Bolt the QTR-1A (or -1RC, but I did some time trials and the analog variety looks fastest for Arduino) sensors into position with M3 nuts and bolts.
  • 31mm diameter lego wheels were used for the feeding-roller mechanism but anything about that size with a bit of grip should do the trick.
  • The body can be made of out anything really. We wanted cheap and fast so we went with cardboard.
    • Operation:
  • Print and cut out one of the paper strips.
  • Color in your desired movement commands.
  • Insert the strip into the upper side of the circular-reader and crank it through. Don't worry about going at a slow or steady pace. The sensors read so quickly you should be able to just rip it through as fast as you can.
  • Hit the Go! button :)

I am working on a 3D Printed glidecam, and I started with a very simple design that will simply work.  I am going to take some of the kinks out of it for v.2, but I am excited to start playing around with the steadycam regardless! (The handle part is glitchy because of sketchup)

I took apart a tripod and used the telescoping leg to make the main shaft.  I then took a 3/8" threaded rod and used epoxy putty to keep it in the ends.  the bottom is a simple brace cut from 1/4 plywood that holds the weights (several large washers). You will need skateboard bearings for this design, because I found those to be very high quality for the price.  You will need a few threaded rods, like the 1/4" used to bolt your camera to the top, but once 3D printed, it snaps on the parts fairly easily, and from using it for a while now, remains steady.

I found it extremely annoying that this simple yet very expensive (to buy) thing has not been posted anywhere. So I made my own based on the spec that I found somewhere.
J1772 is a charging standard for electric cars, the inlet is the part that is found on the car, and if you wanted a dummy inlet to simply plug in the charger to hang it up or keep crud out of the pins, be ready to fork out some $$$, but now you can just print it. Feel free to modify and re-post, but please refer to this original. Thanks.
Update 2013-09-08, this part for sale in a couple places around the net. You will notice that the licence agreement you make when you download this indicates it is not for commercial use, that means you cannot sell it if you downloaded it from here. The only person who has authority to sell this particular part is Joel Clemens.
25$ plus shipping, please contact joelclemens at gmail dot com if interested, thank you for your support :) The unit that is being sold DOES have a latch, which is a recent update not fully published here.
Update: Update 2013-10-03 (unit now available in ABS)
Added a sort-of web store to my blog, to buy this, go here
http://erroneus.myevblog.com/buy-plastic-parts-here/

I have not been selling this particular model for some time. 3D printing is a very slow process.... cast urethane is quicker, and injection molding is the fastest!
The hooded/hook version of this inlet has been my most popular version, which is now available injection molded!

comments.text:
Thanks for posting Grahm, yes, I do know about the EMW project, and I am working with an individual to create a chademo charger out of it. The main issue with the EMW 12kw charger is that it is not isolated which can be a hazard if you have an exposed pack like in a DIY conversion, or a leaf, a ground fault can brick the car (can drive, but cannot charge) until it is un-bricked at a dealership.
I also come from the DIY EV crowd, so I understand you may not be familiar with the leaf when comparing to a home-built EV.
The leaf has an on-board 3.3kw charger, this is what the j1772 connector goes to. (newer models have a 6kw option). at 240V, the input current cannot go over 16amps with the 3.3kw version. The leaf has another option to use an off-board charger for higher power and faster charging, (up to 50kw), the connection standard for that is a japanese standard called CHAdeMO. Which is why i stress the importance of getting an open source chademo charger.

description.text:
Plenty of nice cool beer in the icebox.
But, as soon as you take it out, it starts warming up.
So, think out of the (ice)box.
We need an icebox extension. A 3D printed icebox extension!
It actively cools a bottle, tin or glass of beer outside the box.
A small Peltier element (4x4 cm) is used, which is a low cost heat pump. It transports heat from one side to the other. As soon as electric current flows through the Peltier element, one heat sink heats up, while the other cools down. Peltier elements and heat sinks are common products in hobby electronics shops. At the hot side you really need a large heatsink, otherwise the cold side will heat up as wel. If the hot heatsink is large enough and the fan powerfull, no additional electronics are needed:
http://www.aliexpress.com/snapshot/6324491655.html
supplies complete units with fan and heatsinks for about $18,-
Maybe the printed parts need some modification to fit the sizes (see photo of white box).
This printed gadget has a triple function.
The double wall (infill about 30%) serves as a thermal insulator.
It houses the Peltier element with the two heat sinks (cold one on top).
It holds a fan at the bottom to cool the lower heat sink.

title: Nexus 5 Magnetic Charging Car Dock

description.text: Magnetic car dock for a Nexus 5. Designed to go into a a standard phone car mount, but provides a magnetic surface with wireless qi charging capabilities. The icon is not in the middle of this version of the dock.

Install 4 N48 1/2 by 1/8 inch neodymium magnets (such as these) and a QI charging PCB (I think I ordered this one, but I don't quite remember), and then place in a normal car dock. Plug in the charger and just set your phone on the dock! With a bluetooth receiver in the car, you can set up Tasker or something to start up car mode and use something like Torque or Car Home Ultra to make your phone more useful in the car. I have Tasker read the magnetic sensor and start up Car Home Ultra if it notices a field over a particular threshold while in landscape mode. I recommend covering the front surface with something like plasti-dip before use, so that there's a bit more friction between the phone and the dock.

This is a chess set that I designed to learn some new skills with sketchup. The rounded bases of the pieces are weighted and sit on concave squares. It makes for an interesting twist to the standard chess board. Special thanks to PerryT for the idea for the board base. This is a marathon of a print, roughly 60 hours went into this project and I can tell you it was no easy task. Make no mistake though, if you want to take your 3D printing to the next level or you are an avid chess fan this project is for you. Finnish this print and you will be among the masters of the printing world, you exploits and heroism will be spoken of far and wide by hobbyists and professionals alike. Good luck and God speed! Donate Update 3/18/13: I have added a single Pawn .stl along with .stls for a full set of Rooks, Knights, Bishops, King and queen. One includes the Knight that needs support and the other set is for the two piece Knight that needs to be glues together.

All the pieces of the board can be printed without support and at 10% infill.  Anything above 10% will add considerably to the print time but will result in a stronger and heavier build overall.  
1.) Print 8 Pawns in white and 8 pawns in black.  
2.) Print 2 Rooks, 2 Knights, 2 Bishops, 1 Queen and 1 King in both black and white.  
3.) Print 32 Base pieces in grey or in the color opposite of the piece.  
4.) Print 32 Board Squares in black and 32 in white.  
5.) Print the Board Base in grey or back.  Print 4 corners, 8 edge pieces and 4 center pieces.  
6.) The Base pieces are designed to be weighted with pennies or lead shot.  Add 5 pennies to each base and super-glue in place.  
7.) The base pieces and chess pieces should be sanded lightly to create a good fit and glued together.  
8.) The Board pieces should be sanded lightly to ensure a snug fit on the base.  The base and the squares should be glued into place after being test fit to make sure that all the corners fit well.  
9.) Have fun!

description.text:
It's often annoying to make dotted line with a pencil !
With the dotted lines ruler you can make dotted lines as easily as you make normal lines.
All types of pens, pencils, felt pens and even airbrushes can be used with the dotted lines ruler.
It is 15 cm long, so you can mesure things like with a normal ruler.
Geometry will never be the same ! Also, if you're interrested, join my discord server to discuss about 3d printing, arduino, processing, ... and find many interresting electronic project ideas : https://discord.gg/WydDuDU

I was doing my math homework. I had to make a dotted line on a geometric figure. I found it was hard and annoying to make it, so I decided to make something that could help me.
I printed my ruler and tested it on a sheet paper. It worked perfectly !
note : it works better when the pencil is very sharp

description.text:
Single rotor Wankel rotor engine for display. This is derived from the Grabcad model by Ravi Yadav (http://grabcad.com/library/wankel-engine-2) and converted into a 3d printable option. It will require some gluing and a piece of plexi-glass for the back. You can printout a back plate but i didn't like having the back covered. Enjoy
UPDATE
added a back plate just in case.

Do not scale down! gears are too fine to be printed any smaller. You will have to glue the outer gear to the rotor and the crank to the shaft [don't do this until you have a plexi-glass piece cut out for the back :) ] You will also have to sand a few of the parts so the spin freely. Enjoy and let me know what you think and if you made it.

description.text:
THIS IS NOW FULLY WORKING AND PRINTABLE.  
This is my version of the Buck Rogers XZ-31 Rocket Gun. It is one of the toy ray guns produced by Daisy in 1934. It was based on the gun carried by the popular "Buck Rogers" comic strip character.  
The XZ-31 Rocket Pistol, a 9 ½-inch toy gun that produced a distinctive “pop!” sound, retailed for 50 cents and was made of stamped metal. It was the first of six Buck Rogers toy guns manufactured over the next two decades by Daisy Manufacturing Co..   
My 3D printable version has a spring trigger but does not actually pop or work it was designed just for display. I've wanted this ray gun ever since I saw it back in the 70's when a friend of mine got one from his dad for his birthday one year.  
It may not be the real thing but it was fun to build and will look great once printed and painted.

Please Note: The Bck_Hndl file is a mirror of Frnt_Hndl. You do not need any of the trigger capture on the Bck_Hndl file. I was unable to cut it all away with my current software. When assembling the gun please file off or break away any of the trigger capture still remaining on the Bck_Hndl part.
pretty cool!

Recommended minimum print settings: 0.2mm layer height, 100% infill, 3 shells.
Print time (0.2mm layer height, 100% infill, 3 shells): approximately 1h15m.
This flashlight is an awesome project for learning to solder. If you are interested in making this flashlight then check out the website of the manufacturer and consider buying their kit. It's super simple to build and only takes a few minutes. Checkout the link below.
http://www.jayconsystems.com/batteryless-flashlight-solder-kit.html
Thanks to Jaycon for the fun kit.
Notes: The button is designed to be held in place by some small pegs. All you should have to do if it is printed correctly is press on the button hard enough and it will crack the pegs and allow you to use the button. Depending on how you print it they may or not print correctly. The best way to print it is with a raft and with the LED end of the case aimed down into the board and support on. This will hold the button in the correct place and should only print support inside the indent for the LED. Support is also recommended for the rear cap of the light. The best way to print that should be pretty obvious. Good luck!

I have included both the original AutoCAD files that I made and an STL file for each part so that you can print your own without having to export it from AutoCAD.
To make the model I just used basic shapes and the solid subtraction tool. It was super easy and I would love to see someone build upon what I have designed.

description.text:
As part of Francis Bitonti and Xuedi Chen's vertical studio at the architecture school of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, teams of 3 were given the task to design a paste extruding 3d printer. Our team initially put together a Printrbot Simple Maker's Edition, and using the basic concepts behind this printer, as well as inspiration drawn from the PiMaker, designed our own.
The main features of the PiBot are a flexible dual extruder system combined with a rotating polar bed. This grants us the ability to both print one object with a combination of materials from the two extruders, as well as print two of the same object at the same time, due to the rotating bed.
Team: Nicholas Nord, Hiroki Sawai, Lauren Famularo
Firmware forked from: https://github.com/Printrbot/Marlin

The only changes to the firmware that were made are that the hot end is disabled.
List of parts:
9 motors
2 100ml syringes
2 18in smooth rods
2 16in threaded rods
8 257mm smooth rods
4 200mm threaded rods
2 end stops

12 8mm linear bearings

title: MHC CLASS I H-2DB COMPLEXED WITH A SENDAI VIRUS NUCLEOPROTEIN PEPTIDE

description.text:
These are stl files for a molecular structure from the PDB (RCSB) database, a component of the Immune System named the MHC. MHC molecules can bind small peptides from different sources, thereby alerting the immune system in case of infection or cancer.   
I separated the peptide from the MHC, with the idea to check if I can print them separately and then assemble them and get a good fit. This is still to be tested and news will be posted here on outcome.  
I have printed successfully the MHC complexed with beta-2 Microglobulin, chains A and B of the pdb file (this is one of the two file you can download). The molecule was printed by selecting the "supports" option of the printer at 10% as thickness. The settings for the printing were 30% fill, 0,2 mm layer thickness, shell normal.  
Taking out the supports after printing takes a while and is kind of a zen job in particular for the holes in the structure, but if you remember to make them very light in the printing options, it is a quite straightforward job, just requires a little patience.  
I am now printing a new one, and the peptide (which is the second file to download). Will see if the peptide will enter the binding groove easily.  
If you print one, thanks for posting the photos! See mines in the photo gallery.

I can't fit the peptide into the MHC pocket, although it is easy to see how the fit "would be". Likely for loading the peptide, the pocket of the MHC molecule "opens up" and then somehow "clamps" the peptide in place. So although the peptide does fit the pocket, once it is outside it can't be simply slided in from above, without opening the pocket first. All wild speculations here, only based on "3D printing data" :)

description.text: This thing originally started out as a Christmas light hanging tool but quickly turned into something customizable for many purposes. This tool screws onto the end of a pole. You put your Christmas lights, wire, string, etc into it and lift it on to a waiting hook. The default values for the threads has been tested on a broom handle and a long pole from my local hardware store. Included are two ready-to-print designs. One for hanging lights, and the other for hanging rings (up to 1/8in 3mm thick 5/8in-1.4in 15-36mm wide). I successfully printed the design without support using a .4mm nozzle and .2mm layer height. I used 50% infill because was worried about strength, but after printing I found that it could be reduced. This thing uses the thread library from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8793 . I've included the version I used for your convenience.
This zip tie mount is compatible with Misumi aluminium extrusions.
blue-core foam glider made to toss with my son.

I cut this out of 1/2" thick blue foam with my oversized shapeoko.
You could also do it by hand from a printed template. This foam is readily available from Lowes for around $10 a sheet (the glider used 1/16th of a sheet). You are looking for "1/2-in x 4-ft x 8-ft Extruded Polystyrene Insulated Sheathing". I assembled it with hot glue (which melts the foam if you don't let it cool a little before application). Stuck an M5 bolt (30mm?) in the nose to balance it so the glide trajectory was better. Tried to print a little model, but slic3r barfed on the mangled stl that came out of sketchup. Looks like kisslicer does better, but I haven't tested it yet.

Another MAKER Club project that crosses over with the Elementary Art Club!! Although this project was so popular I ended up doing it for anybody that was interested! It created quite a buzz!
I think it also really demonstrated the power of knowing how to do even a little bit of code/command line and how creativity and art blend with the technology and the math/science behind it!

Students designed snowflakes on http://snowflakes.barkleyus.com and then I ran them through a few processing steps to get them ready to print. I used a mac so my command line functions may look a bit different to someone using a PC. To summarize (maybe I should do my first Instructable for the whole thing) the process I did was:
Use convert to make the files I got bitmaps
Used potrace to make DXF graphics out of them
Use OpenSCAD and linear extrude to make them 3D
Use command line Slic3r to make my gcode
I was able to do them in an entire batch and really save myself a lot of work doing command line!!

description.text: Life Prosperity Health

I think the name says it all; this is a kiteboard fin based on the Liquid Force 'GTS 2.0' model (so if you have a board that fits these you can use this 3D printed version no problems). This is not just a test piece, but I now use these 3D printed fins on my board. I've been printing them on an 'Up! Plus 2' printer using the 0.15mm layer settings and solid fill for strength. I have also been using a small amount of acetone just to finish off the outside surfaces, but the quality off the 'Up! Plus 2' has been pretty good so you don't necessarily have to do this. Check out my blog to read how these were developed and tested (http://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/category/kitesurfing/) All I can say is have fun out on the water, and let me know how you go!!

Create a jewelry or gift box, choose from hundreds of shapes. Customize the top with infinitely variable filigree designs. You may also print an insert to snap in behind the filigree to make it stand out.

This customizer script allows you to make an infinite variety of boxes. You can choose from heart shapes, Jewish stars, crosses, n-sided boxes, ovaloids, racetrack shapes, and rounded rectangular boxes (with a variable radius corner). Then you can create a filigree pattern on top of your container. There are a number of variables that control the pattern generation, as well as multiple pattern generators. Be sure to play with the centering as well ( I personally like the sunburst effects.) You may play with the variables to your heart's content. But when you have designed a container that you like you should do the following:
  • Be sure that the container you have designed fits into your build volume for your printer. If not, reduce either the height or the size of the box until you can print it.
  • Decide whether or not you want an insert in your box. I like to print the insert in a contrasting color to bring out the box top pattern.
  • Print each individual part, the box body, the box top, and optionally the insert. This is controlled by the "customizer" part variable.
    • You may find that the top is not a tight fit into the body, or that the insert doesn't snap into the top. In that case you should tweak the print extrusion variables in "customizer". The parts may be sensitive to the size of your nozzle or extrusion size.

description.text:
Are you tired of high quality manufactured minifig heads that have faces printed on them? Do you want to retire that goofy face of yellow with one of printed filament?  
If you have answered yes to any of these questions then this might be the mesh for you. This mesh comes with no guarantee or warrantee of suitability for any particular purpose. Caught in the wild and never tamed, these feral heads are yours for the taking. If they bite your fingers, don't say I didn't warn you.

Printed in gold bumat filament at 0.1mm layer height on a replicator2, no supports and no raft on an acrylic plate. Easy to remove thanks to the limited contact area. Extended snouts have built in support that removes easily with a knife.  
If the head doesn't fit, try harder. If it still doesn't fit, you're holding it wrong. Oh, wait, wrong script: try using a knife (on the printed head, not the minifig). In all seriousness, when I did the first test prints at 0.2mm layer height they were too small off the printer (a little knife work fixed them up, though), but after adjusting when I dropped to 0.1mm layer height they were too loose and I reverted to the original dimensions. That's a variance of ~0.3mm in diameter -- go makerbot.  
Watch out for failed extrusion toward the end, the replicator 2 at least has a problem with this (it isn't the bumat filament, it is more reliable than any sold by makerbot). The problem seem to be worse when printing singly so print them in a group -- they want the company anyway.

title: Parametric set top box foot pedestal

description.text:
Two problems exist in my household: 1) my Comcast DVR is on the lower shelf of our media cabinet, and the door frame blocks the IR receiver, and 2) in the master bedroom we have our set-top boxes stacked, so anything with ventilation on top can overheat.
I designed this parametric foot pedestal so it could be altered for use with (hopefully) any set-top box.  I hope it works for you, too.

All of the variables in the OpenSCAD file that you might want to adjust are at the top of the .scad file. The names are pretty self-explanatory, but here's an overview of what they do:
  • top_od: the outer diameter of the top of the pedestal
  • top_id: the inner diameter for the recessed area on top. This is to accommodate the rubber feet at the bottom of your set-top box. If you don't want it, set this to 0.
  • top_hole_depth: how deep the recessed part is
  • lower_od: the diameter of the base of the pedestal
  • lower_ring_id: the inner diameter of the o-ring, if you want to use one. I picked McMaster part #4061T165, which has a square cross section.
  • lower_ring_od: the outer diameter of the o-ring
  • oring_thickness: the thickness of the o-ring
  • oring_exposed_thickness: how much of the o-ring you want exposed below the bottom of the pedestal
  • height: how tall the pedestal should be

comments.text:
The temperature limits of ABS/PLA should not be a problem for this part due to the following reasons:
1) This part is simply a key to change the hub between 4wd and 2wd and does not technically even need to be in place after use. In the event that this part did suffer temperature failure it would simply mean that the wheel hub could not be changed between 4wd and 2wd without extra tools.
2) due to the design of the part, the common place is to leave the key attached to its socket via a screw, but temperature failure should not be a problem as the wheel bearings should not get hot unless they fail.

description.text: for 3d ture

I printed at 2mm layer height w/25% fill and 3 shells: the post needs to be strong enough to endure sanding and dropping off of tables and such to the floor. To assemble get some silly putty and a nickel. Sand the bottom of the spherical piece and the post really smooth. These are the parts that the top spins on and too much friction inhibits a good spin. Sand away the imperfections on the outside of the cylinder and the inside of the spherical piece that it slots into. Does not have to be smooth, rough works best, but enough so that the cylinder will slot into the sphere. Don't slot it in until the top is weighted /w the nickel. After sanding press the putty flat (I use a plastic lid) and use the spherical piece to cut out a disc of putty. Press the nickel into the disc. Drop the putty/nickel, putty side down into the spherical piece. Press on the nickel firmly. Slide the cylindrical piece into the spherical piece. Spin it like a standard top. If you get a good spin on a smooth surface it should tip over and spin on the post. Then read about physics to figure out how it works.
The stl file contains both pieces of the top. My practice is to do a print whenever I switch colors until I get three and then make 3 2-color tops.
Video of two tippy tops tipping:
https://www.facebook.com/video.php?v=989043771108304&pnref=story

title: Laird's SCAD Chess Set (updated)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I have been wanting to make this chess set for years. Now that 3D printing is becoming affordable, perhaps I can actually make a physical set. Until then, I am uploading it for others to enjoy. The set is designed to be artistically interesting, but also to illustrate the moves of each piece, with the names labeled, to make Chess approachable for kids. The king has the tallest 'body' and has its name printed in large type to indicate its importance. The circle represents the king's ability to move one space in any direction. The queen is about as tall as the king, with the 'head' indicating that the Queen can move any distance in the eight directions. The knight is shorter, with cubes arranged around a central diamond indicating the eight squares that the knight can jump to. The arrangement of the cubes on the top and the back, and the angle of the supporting head, are intended to evoke a horse's head. The bishop and rook are the same height, with 'heads' indicating their ability to move any distance in either the diagonals or horizontal and vertical. Finally the pawns are the shortest. The 'head' indicates the ability to move forward one square, or capture diagonally. I couldn't think of a way to indicate moving forward two spaces, or capturing en-passent. This is a complete rebuild of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1523 using OpenSCAD. I am now an OpenSCAD convert - it allowed me to express precisely what I wanted, rather than trying to approximate in a GUI. Updated: Ordered a Thing-o-matic, so refreshing this in preparation for printing it. Generated individual STL files for each piece, as the whole set won't fit into a TOM print area.

Print two copies, in two different colors/materials, so that you can tell the two sides apart.
I have uploaded an OpenSCAD file, and also an exported STL file of the whole set, and as individual STL files for each piece. I don't have a 3D printer yet, so I cannot verify that this is printable, but if anyone could print me a set, I'd be happy to pay for it.
The OpenSCAD code is pretty obvious (at least to me).
The units are inches. That is, each piece is 1 (inch) wide, and the tallest piece is 4 (inches) tall. Setting the 'size' and 'offset' variables in the SCAD file will scale the pieces and the spacing of the pieces as desired (if you want to generate and print the whole set in one print, if your printer is big enough). To generate individual pieces from the OpenSCAD file, comment out all but one at the bottom of the SCAD file.
There is some overhang on the knight, but only a quarter inch, which I hope will be printable using an extrusion 3D printer.

comments.text: Glad you like it. I've printed a few sets - it worked pretty well. The overhangs where the cubes stick out were a little tricky, but the following layers were fine. I tweaked the design to make them easier to print. I should get around to uploading it... :-)

title: Rotating Key Chain / Fob... with spinning MakerBot Logo!

description.text:
Every MakerBot owner / user needs one of these on their key ring.
This key fob has an outer / middle / inner ring which spin freely and independently from each other. This makes it a great little 3D printed things that shows what is possible... a real conversation starter that goes everywhere you go.
Easy print with designed in support... on a Replicator 2 the support comes away easily and cleanly leaving the middle and inner rings to spin freely... give it a quick spray with some silicone lubricant (non-greasy and dry finish) to make it spin really well and similar to a bearing. To make it multi-coloured (as pictured) change the filament at 2mm and again at 6mm when using Raft (approx. 1mm thick). If not using Raft then change it at 1mm and 5mm.

On a Replicator 2 this prints best at high resolution (0.10mm) with Raft on, 5 shells and 50% fill to make it almost solid and strong. It doesn't use a lot of filament because it's small.
The designed in support should break away easily from a well set up machine leaving the middle and inner rings to spin freely... but a quick spray of silicone lubricant makes it spin even better.
To make it multi-coloured (as pictured) change the filament at 2mm and again at 6mm when using Raft (approx. 1mm thick). If not using Raft then change it at 1mm and 5mm.

title: Power supply mount for Prusa Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is designed to mount a power supply with a 150x50 mm pattern of (4) M4 tapped holes on one side. Mine is a Sopudar SPD-350W. The printed part shown in the photos is designed for my specific printer, which has a 270 mm rod spacing. The version I have uploaded is slotted to allow it to work with a rod spacing of 262 to 278 mm, or with a power supply whose hole pattern is slightly different. I have included a STEP file to make it easier for you to modify it to suit your needs.

You will need four of each of these:

  • M4 screw, 12 mm length

  • M4 washer

  • M3 screw, 20 mm minimum length

  • M3 washer

  • M3 nut
    • Print four copies of the part. I recommend loosely fitting them on the frame of your Prusa and driving your Z axis to its upper limit to confirm that the position you've chosen doesn't restrict the print head travel or collide with tall parts on the print bed.

A box for the "cleaning tools" that came with a CEL Robox printer.
Modeled after the cardboard box they came in. Each of the four chisels have their own slot, the cover is hinged and it stays closed with a small latch. The model has no tolerances on the hinges, so a little sanding may be required, if the print is inaccurate. A piece of iron wire is needed in the hinges as the kingpin to keep the box base and cover together. Version 2 has changes in dimensions. Bigger hinges and thicker locking clip. It could be possible to use a printed hinge pin with this version. I haven't tried.

description.text: An adjustable belt tensioner for the x-axis of the 3d-printed printrbot. This design was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:50513 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29726

prework: If you need this part, then you will likely need to clean up the printed parts. Make sure the screws and belts go through the holes. It is not necessary for the nuts to fit in their slots.
1) Thread a small screw through the side of the base piece with a nut on the inside. Slide this onto the x-axis mounting point of the printrbot and tighten the screw to secure.
2) Thread a long screw through the smaller piece and put a nut on the other side. Have a small zip-tie handy for the next step.
3) Thread both ends of the x-axis belt through the holes in the sides of the base piece. Pull the belt through until it is tight, then slip the smaller piece between the belt ends with the end of the screw facing up. It should be as low as possible. Use a small zip-tie to secure the belt ends to the smaller piece.
4) Tighten the long screw to tension your belt. The end of it should slip into a hole in the base for stability.
